title: Food & Cooking
description: From Italian classics to American favorites, test your knowledge of cuisine, cooking, and food origins.

questions.question: What country is pizza originally from?
questions.explanation: Modern pizza originated in Naples, Italy, in the 18th century. The classic Margherita pizza was reportedly created in 1889 in honor of Queen Margherita of Italy.

questions.question: What is the main ingredient in guacamole?
questions.explanation: Guacamole is made primarily from mashed avocados. The dish originated with the Aztecs in Mexico and the name comes from the Aztec word 'ahuacamolli.'

questions.question: Which spice is known as the most expensive in the world by weight?
questions.explanation: Saffron is the most expensive spice because each flower produces only three tiny threads, and it takes about 75,000 flowers to produce one pound of saffron.

questions.question: What type of pasta is shaped like little bow ties?
questions.explanation: Farfalle is the bow tie-shaped pasta. The name comes from the Italian word for 'butterflies.' It originated in the Lombardia and Emilia-Romagna regions of Italy.

questions.question: What is the primary grain used to make traditional Japanese sake?
questions.explanation: Sake is a Japanese alcoholic beverage made by fermenting polished rice. It has been brewed in Japan for over 2,000 years.

questions.question: What cooking technique involves briefly plunging food into boiling water, then into ice water?
questions.explanation: Blanching is used to partially cook vegetables, loosen skins on tomatoes or peaches, and preserve color and texture. The ice water stops the cooking process immediately.

questions.question: Which American city is famous for its deep-dish pizza?
questions.explanation: Chicago is famous for its deep-dish pizza, which features a thick, buttery crust pressed into a deep pan with layers of cheese, toppings, and chunky tomato sauce on top.

questions.question: What vitamin is citrus fruit, like oranges and lemons, particularly high in?
questions.explanation: Citrus fruits are rich in Vitamin C, which supports the immune system. British sailors were once called 'limeys' because they ate limes to prevent scurvy on long voyages.

questions.question: Which herb is the key ingredient in traditional Italian pesto sauce?
questions.explanation: Traditional pesto alla genovese is made with fresh basil, garlic, pine nuts, Parmesan cheese, and olive oil. It originated in Genoa, in the Liguria region of Italy.

questions.question: What is the term for cooking meat slowly in its own fat?
questions.explanation: Confit is a French cooking method where meat (traditionally duck or goose) is slowly cooked in its own fat at a low temperature, resulting in incredibly tender meat.

questions.question: Which country is the world's largest producer of coffee?
questions.explanation: Brazil has been the world's largest coffee producer for over 150 years, producing about one-third of the world's coffee supply.

questions.question: What is the name of the classic French soup made with onions and topped with melted cheese on bread?
questions.explanation: French onion soup (soupe a l'oignon) features caramelized onions in beef broth, topped with a crouton and melted Gruyere cheese. It dates back to at least the 18th century.

questions.question: What is the main ingredient in hummus?
questions.explanation: Hummus is made primarily from cooked, mashed chickpeas blended with tahini, lemon juice, garlic, and olive oil. It has been eaten in the Middle East for centuries.

questions.question: What does 'al dente' mean when cooking pasta?
questions.explanation: Al dente is Italian for 'to the tooth,' meaning pasta should be cooked until it is still slightly firm when bitten. This is considered the ideal texture in Italian cooking.

questions.question: Which nut is used to make marzipan?
questions.explanation: Marzipan is a confection made from ground almonds, sugar, and sometimes egg whites. It has been popular in European baking and candy-making since the Middle Ages.
